data.name: UTF-8 aware string length
data.description:
UTF-8 is a variable length character encoding (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTF-8)

While UTF-8 is binary safe (in the sense that UTF-8 encoded strings never contain zeros) standard libc string functions do not work properly on UTF-8 input as they operate under the premise that one character spans exactly one byte.

As an example, `strlen("müde")` returns 5 even though "müde" is comprised of 4 UTF-8 characters (m,ü,d,e).

Your job is to write a UTF-8 aware string length function that returns the number of UTF-8 character code points contained in a UTF-8 encoded buffer.

`uint32_t utf8_strlen(char *);`

UTF-8 encodings that exceed 4 bytes are considered invalid input (as they are not currently mapped in the unicode standard) so your input will only consist of UTF-8 characters that can be encoded as 4 bytes or less.

If your function encounters invalid input (illegal UTF8, e.g. missing continuation bytes, etc) it must return zero.
